name: Yellow-billed Hornbill
description: A smaller hornbill species with distinctive white-spotted wing feathers. Both males and females have a long yellow to yellowish-orange beak; males also have a low casque extending to the tip. The bare skin around the eyes is gray.
spread_note: From Ethiopia and Somalia to Uganda and Tanzania
food_note: Insects and other invertebrates, occasionally fruits
proportions: Body length 23–29 cm (beak 6.5–8 cm), tail length 18–21 cm, wing length 16–19 cm, weight 170–275 g
attractions: Its favorite foods are grasshoppers, locusts, and crickets. It’s often seen with mongooses, which flush out insects for it to easily pick up.
breeding: The first hornbills arrived in 2004 from the wild. This pair became the founders of our breeding program, and since 2010, visitors can see both them and some of their offspring.
